text: Effects of <extra_id_0> interleukin-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on human peripheral blood mononuclear cell responses to Cryptococcus neoformans , Candida albicans , and lipopolysaccharide .
Deactivation of mononuclear phagocytes is critical to limit the inflammatory response but can be detrimental in the face of progressive infection .

We compared the effects of the deactivating cytokine <extra_id_0> interleukin 10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) on human peripheral blood mononuclear cell ( PBMC ) responses to lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) , Cryptococcus neoformans , and Candida albicans .

<extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> effected dose - dependent inhibition of <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) release in PBMC stimulated by LPS and C . neoformans , with significant inhibition seen with 0.1 U / ml and greater than 90 % inhibition noted with 10 U / ml .

In contrast , even at doses as high as 100 U / ml , <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibited <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> release in response to C . albicans by only 50 % .
<extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> profoundly inhibited release of <extra_id_0> IL-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> from PBMC stimulated by all three stimuli .

<extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA and release was inhibited even if <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was added up to 8 h after cryptococcal stimulation .

In contrast , inhibition of <extra_id_0> IL-1 beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA was of lesser magnitude and occurred only when <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was added within 2 h of cryptococcal stimulation .
<extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibited translocation of NF-kappaB in response to LPS but not the fungal stimuli .

All three stimuli induced <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production in PBMC , although over 10-fold less <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was released in response to C . neoformans compared with LPS and C . albicans .

Thus , while <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has deactivating effects on PBMC responses to all three stimuli , disparate stimulus - and response - specific patterns of deactivation are seen .

Inhibition by <extra_id_0> IL-10 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> of proinflammatory cytokine release appears to occur at the level of gene transcription for <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and both transcriptionally and posttranscriptionally for <extra_id_0> IL-1beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
